key_points: President Joe Biden said Derek Chauvin's conviction in George Floyd's killing is a step forward against systemic racism.
Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris emphasized that the fight for justice and policing reform is far from over.
They urged Congress to pass the George Floyd policing reform bill.
Biden and Harris highlighted the need to confront hatred and systemic racism beyond legal reforms.
Harris, the first Black woman vice president, spoke on racism's impact on the country's potential and promise of justice for all.
Biden interacted with Floyd's family, offering comfort and seeing Floyd's death as a world-changing event.
Chauvin was convicted of two counts of murder and one of manslaughter after the jury deliberated for about 10 hours over two days.
Biden had earlier expressed hope for 'the right verdict' while the jury was sequestered, a comment that drew attention.
The verdict's aftermath remains a challenge for Biden, who aims to address policing racism while maintaining support for law enforcement.
Responses to the verdict included relief and a renewed push for policing reform legislation among lawmakers from both parties.
spokespersons: Brock Hunter (criminal defense attorney, past president of the Minnesota Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers)
